Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: US-Ignite: Creation of Situational Awareness for Emergency Response and Management Using Next Generation Gigabit Communication Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This US Ignite project aims to develop and demonstrate the integration and distribution of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) maps and Light Detection And Ranging (LIDAR) type imaging in support of emergency management. A major stumbling block for successful response and recovery in the event of an emergency is the lack of actionable, timely and reliable information flows between the regional emergency management office (EMO) to the incident command (IC) and then to incident responders in the field and from the IC to the EMO. There are multiple informational flows between these coordinating entities and stakeholders such as utility crews, transportation managers, health services and the like. Emergency response benefits from having all parties aware of the "ground truth" associated with the incident. Because of large data set sizes, current disaster response relies on pre-generated static maps with overlaid physical notations. There is a lack of real-time method to integrate data, particularly high density GIS and image applications for emergency response needs. This project shows the value of high-bandwidth communications in emergencies.

The project combines GIS maps and LIDAR imagery and transmits the combined data to public safety offices via on-demand, Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI)-provided Software Defined Network (SDN) connections for performance and authorization reasons. Several public safety training exercises using the enhanced data will provide demonstrations of the system's usefulness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a disaster, a delay in information transfer can mean the difference between life and death. At Rochester Institute of Technology, a team of faculty lead by Dr. Nirmala Shenoy worked on a project funded by National Science Foundation and US Ignite.  The project effort resulted in the development of a new protocol that will bypass the Internet Protocol and thereby bypass other Internet traffic and deliver emergency data between incident center and first responders in a timely and reliable manner. 

The emergency management requirements for the project were provided by Dr. Jennifer Schneider, Principal of RIT’s Collaboratory for Resiliency & Recovery, co-principal investigator on the project. Dr. Schneider identified  dense data sharing an ongoing need in emergency response.

Based on the communications needs during an emergency, the new protocol named as the Emergency Internet Bypass Lane Protocol (EIBL), establishes a bypass lane on the Internet, without disrupting its normal operations. The EIBL protocol operates below the Internet Protocol (IP) i.e. Layer 3 of the network protocol stack. When the EIBL protocol is deployed in all routers in the domain, the protocol can capture emergency traffic entering the network at one point, for example, the incident command center and deliver it to first-responders elsewhere.

Currently in the event of network link or component failures, there are no guarantees that  information will be delivered reliably or in a timely manner. This is because current routing protocols, namely OSPF and BGP determine routes using network-wide or global connectivity information, and the process of updating the routes in the event of failures is sluggish. EIBL adopts a new approach, where modules and virtual structures exiting in networks are used to provide routing infromation, by abstracting the connnectivity information  in labels assigned to routers. Multiple labels carry multiple connectivity information and are able to provide multiple paths for information delivery. In the event of a link failure, failover to another label and another path is almost immediate on failure detection. The tables used for routing by EIBL do not increase with increase in network size and hence are scalable, as they are based on local connectivity information.

The EIBL protocol was compared for performance improvements with OSPF and BGP running in identical topologies established over the GENI test beds. Convergence times, impact ratio (which is the number of nodes that update their information) and control overhead in the event of a topology change were recorded. Also, the routing table sizes for each protocol was recorded. The performance comparison was demonstrated in real time on 12th May 2017, to regional responders in Rochester NY, with the Incident Command Center at Rochester Institute of Technology, and US Ignite representatives. The project was also demonstrated at GENI NICE conferences and the Smart Cities Connect Conference on 23rd June 2017.

The convergence time which comprises of failure detection and recovery time was several seconds with OSPF and BGP, while with EIBL protocol this was a few seconds, depending on where the failure occurred. While OSPF supports link-based failure detection which is hardly noticeable, the recovery time can be several seconds and packet delivery during this period is not guaranteed – this can adversely impact rescue operations during an emergency. With its low operational complexity, the EIBL protocol is capable of supporting robust communications during emergency.

Intellectual Merit: The novel solution to decouple routing from routing table sizes and routing process complexity will have a significant impact on information forwarding in a timely and reliable manner. The protocol effectively tunnels the emergency data through the networks without being impacted by the traffic that traverses layer 3 and above and its operations are independent of other protocols and operations at Layer 3 and above. The routing technique adopted by EIBL, provides quick recovery in the event of failure, requires limited information dissemination, as the routing information is carried in the multiple labels that can be auto-assigned to the routers. The configuration needs of the protocol are also minimal. 

Broader Impacts: The project represents the foundational step in marrying our societal needs with the construct of our communications systems. As the number of local, national and international crises increases, response organizations must be able to leverage every informational source in a very time constricted and virtually responsive manner.  In that way,  technology allows the human organizations to spend its resources on response, not informational organization and communication. This effort has two distinct impacts: (1) creation of a method for sharing  disparate informational sources to support emergency response and use of rich community emergency response related information and (2) building of a capability and method for time sensitive information sharing between stakeholders engaged in a literal life and death crisis.  Since situational awareness is key to response, this information sharing methodology is a dynamic shift in emergency management.
